content.description: This route has a good deal of varied climbing: crack, a traverse, an arete, some face and is the only route in the Jungle where you can easily top out on good rock to enjoy the view! A good warm up line that starts 5.6, then a 5.7 traverse leads to a 5.8 arete that finishes on a 5.9 face.
content.protection: The 5.6 off width start is used only for gear, the abundant edges provide all one needs to set two #5s or a #5 and a #6. Two 5 ft. runners, five shoulder length runners, and five quick draws gets you to chains.  One bolt mid way through is a bit off to the right.  This sometimes happens in the Jungle when a conscientious route-setter chooses better rock over better reach location.
content.location: Near the end of the "Distant Drum Area" and the "Village Wall," this line requires a 4th class scramble up the talus chute for about 20 feet.  This is the same approach to gain access to the chimney which leads to the top.

content.description: Great route on good rock. Clip a bolt then pull up into a stellar finger crack. Finish on edges with some arete-slapping action. Well protected, but you'll understand the name once you're at the base...
content.protection: Bolts, thin gear.
content.location: Lower jungle, Distant drum area.

climbs.name: Swinging on Webs
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Phyllis Suggett, Zac Warren (8/6/12)

content.description: This route starts on flaky rock albeit well bolted.  A little bit of delicate, four-point movement quickly gets you onto stellar rock.  From here, the climbing is exceptional and on edgy, big moves that lead you to the left of the face.  Third bolt from the top and the last bolt are the crux.  Wild, fun, and zesty!  If it weren't for the few moves on poor rock at the bottom, this would be 4 stars for sure!
content.protection: 11 quick draws, and 1 shoulder length runner gets you to the anchor shared with "Swinging from Limbs."
content.location: Between "She Jane" and left of "Swinging from Limbs."

content.description: This fun route starts with some great moves that lead on to a blunt arete and some less than stellar rock.  Do not despair, the rest of the 75 feet of climbing IS on stellar rock and finishes with the crux. There are two back and forths on the arete but you end up in the middle of the face pulling the 11a move to the anchor.  Lots of fun! The second time you are on the right of the arete there is a bit of a reach move for shorter climbers.  A left hand NOT obvious side pull can make the difference.
content.protection: Twelve bolts lead to an anchor.  Quick draws and some runners for clipping long.  The long clips are recommended under the roof, at the roof and just past the roof.
content.location: Just north and up hill from "She Jane" the arete forms a small overhang over the trail which is very near to a large Aspen Tree. On the same face and just left is Swinging On Webs.

climbs.name: The Source of De Nile
climbs.fa: Zac Warren, Phyllis and Roy Suggett

content.description: An easy enough looking .10a (bull) that will school you on judging a book by its cover!  Jams are varied and difficult on this pumpy, sustained, frustrating, and exhilarating .11a route!
content.protection: Bring everything you have up to to a #5.  Chains at the top with a quick link.
content.location: This route is just south of "Jared Diamond's Tower" - can't miss the tower - it's 'collapsed' and the trail leads under it!

climbs.name: Simeon Smile
climbs.fa: Zac Warren, Phyllis and Roy Suggett

content.description: Crux is mantling the shelf and clipping the fourth bolt!
content.protection: 5 quick draws and runners leads to chains.
content.location: On the "Commuter Wall" in the Distant Drum Area just north of the second mountaineer's trail.

content.description:
A stellar line up solid stone! As fun as it is steep,

She Jane

offers a number of great moves over quality rock. A route to remember.

Follow bolts up a steep face to a short hand crack. Break left to a small ledge and fire an intimidating roof. Finish on a ledge at a two bolt anchor.  A classic line with classic movement.
content.protection: Seven draws and one long runner for eight bolts. Finish at a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Deep in the

Distant Drum

,

She Jane

sits in a cove shortly after the leaning

Jared Diamond Tower

.

content.description: Moving over the head wall is the crux.  Keep in mind the blocks at the base of this head wall look dubious though they could not be moved.
content.protection: Quick draws and runners.
content.location: Mid way along the Village Wall in the Distant Drum Area where the trail drops down into some shady trees.

climbs.name: Scapular Arete
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Phyllis Suggett, Scott Carson

content.description: This fun arete starts in a crack prior to reaching the arete.  The crux is between the second and third bolts that has you barn-dooring right on to the face.  Big holds and good feet get you through with a smile.
content.protection: One each of BD .3 through .75, three QDs and some runners for the two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route is just right of Monkey Shoulder and actually climbs the "Shoulder" on the north side of the arete.

content.description: This is a well-bolted entry-level sport route.  The crux is high up just below the ledge.
content.protection: Five quick draws and a few runners.
content.location: Between "The Source of De Nile" and "Me Tarzan" immediately north of the Jared Diamond Tower.

content.description: This ever steepening line is on deceptively good rock.  The deep and numerous pockets create a jug fest that is appreciated at the well overhung last bolt and crux.  Really fun climbing!
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: In the right and north facing dihedral that has the crack called "Forbidden Coast Line."  This line is on the face just right of "Forbidden Coast Line" but shares the same anchor.

content.description:
A solid crack climb up some of the best rock in

the Jungle

. Begin in a right sweeping crack and follow this onto a steep face. When the final crack ends, traverse right onto the ledge and shared anchor of

She Jane

. Killer moves up a varied break, end the climb at a shared two bolt anchor. Good, intense climbing with solid protection.
content.protection: A single set of cams and stoppers up to 2.5 inches.
content.location:
On the far, right end of the

Distant Drum

, this climb is found soon after the collapsed

Jared Diamond Tower

. This wall stands alone in a nice cove at the bottom of a small hill.

Me Tarzan

is the thin crack about seven feet left of

She Jane

.

content.description: This finger crack starts with 15' of vertical jamming then diverges left and right into thin finger locks and small edges.
content.protection: See gear in picture below used on FA.  Consider off sets a must.  This leads you to chains shared by "See No Evil."
content.location: In the "Distant Drum Area", mid way through the Village Wall, at a low point in the trail surrounded by trees.

content.description: This route takes pro well and is very straight forward.
content.protection: .5(s) to 1.0(s) to the chain anchor.
content.location: Just off the trail (behind a tree) along the "Commuter Wall" in the "Distant Drum Area" and also just right of the route "Simeon Smile"

climbs.name: Forbidden Coast Line
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Phyllis Suggett, Scott Carson

content.description: The crux is, as usual, at the top or perhaps just getting use to the strange and unique rock of this line.  What looks like suspect rock will surprise you as stellar and very climbable.  You could link this line with "Monkey Shoulder" just left of the shoulder thus skipping the chimney (which is fun).
content.protection: BD .5 through-#3 up the crack to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Ten feet right of "Monkey Shoulder" on the north side of the "shoulder/arete and on bubbly but hard rock.

content.description: This somewhat short finger crack is a bit spicy for the shorter climber who cannot reach the the wider hand jams for a rest.  It takes gear well and has some fun moves!
content.protection: Small cams and nuts gets you to chains.
content.location: This route is in a shady low area at the beginning of the "Village Wall."

content.description:
A mixed route and one of the longest routes in The Jungle.  If the leader cleans the route, a 60 meter rope will just barely work; 70 meter rope is recommended.  The crux is near the top of this fun forearm festival.

Start on the south side of the "monkey's shoulder" (face moves) then move through an easy chimney to a discontinuous crack that leads to a large block.  Here is the first bolt prior to heading left back into the crack.  This first clip is also the two bolt anchor for other climbs on the north side of the shoulder. After working your way through a loose crack and another bolt head up to a large bush where you then traverse left onto the glorious face and through 7 more bolts on ever-steepening, good rock.

You could also use the anchor on the block as the anchor for the first pitch, thus making this a two pitch route and eliminating the possible need for a longer rope.
content.protection: One 5, one 4, one 3, one 2, one 1, one .3, and one Metolius 00 along with 5 shoulder length runners, one four foot runner, and 5 quick draws get you to chains.
content.location: At the end of the Distant Drum area and just around the corner and north of the down chute.  Half way through this chute you can see the upper face of this route.

content.description:
Start to the left of a brushy low angle corner below a smooth sheet of crimson patina. A few long moves to positive edges and a touchy mantle lead to the third bolt and the first crux, a delicate rightward traverse. Don't peel off these awkward moves and you'll be rewarded with a rest below a small broken roof.

Tackle said roof and establish on the face above, following an offset seam with the occasional edge or crack feature and fighting the growing pump by milking unobvious rests. The climbing gets steeper, thinner and more technical, eventually leading into an intimidating blocky area. The route takes the path of least resistance through this, heading left to an obvious stance where a large cube used to reside. Things may appear a bit hollow in the area but we were ruthless with the cleaning and what's left is not going anywhere.

Take note of the 9th bolt a ways out right and don't get greedy with an early clip: it's easily reachable from the stance, not so much from below while pumped.

Gingerly surmount the last of the blocks and veer right, aiming for the faint dihedral which forms the upper headwall. Take a deep breath and fire the last 30' of slightly overhanging rock, pulling long technical moves on small but positive edges. If the pump catches up with you before you clip the chains expect a long clean ride!

The route got its name from the numerous trips we had to take up and down the poop chute and the massive amounts of choss we tossed off the top before we could even start cleaning the face. As usual in the Jungle, the recipe for a rad new line is a (dumb) vision, lots of sweat and time with the trusty hammer/crowbar/steel brush combo!
content.protection: 11 bolts to chain anchors. The 9th bolt can be hard to spot, rock quality dictated a placement a bit further right than we'd have liked on the side of a small prow.
content.location:
The fastest approach is from the top. Follow the directions found on the Distant Drum main page to find the poop chute which deserves the end of the Village Wall and the Planet of the Apes. Make a right (heading South) at the bottom of the chute, round the corner and you'll find the route, easily identifiable by a giant sheet of red patina at the bottom of an orange face (and a large destruction area at the base).

If you have a dog, want to warm up along the way or dislike via ferratas you can park at the Lower Jungle and take a 25-30 minutes stroll depending on the weight of your pack.

content.description: The crack starts in a right facing dihedral that gives many edges and leads to a shelf half way through the route.  Then you switch to a left facing dihedral that takes you past an Xed block that needs a big crowbar...coming soon.
content.protection: Good pro from .5 to #2s with some runners required will get you to chains.
content.location: This route is just left of the shorter crack "Congolese Crescendo" and the face between is a great top rope.

content.description:
This fun sport line, named after the Disney song from the Jungle Book, is located at the very end of the Commuter Wall and as of 06/11/12 is the furthest route from the parking lot.

Fun crimpy moves lead to a 5.10 crux and a headwall where toe/heel hooks can be usefull. Six bolts with chain anchors.
content.protection: You need just the bare necessities....6 sport draws and something for the anchors.
content.location: The very end of the Commuter Wall before what is now being called the Village Wall.
